data.value: -point discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) with the efficient Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) algorithm .
FFT (Fast Fourier Transform) refers to a way the discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) can be calculated efficiently, by using symmetries in the calculated terms. The symmetry is highest when
is a power of 2, and the transform is therefore most efficient for these sizes. For poorly factorizable sizes,
uses Bluestein's algorithm  and so is never worse than O(
). Further performance improvements may be seen by zero-padding the input using
y[k] = np.sum(x * np.exp(-2j * np.pi * k * np.arange(n)/n))

we reach the Nyquist frequency and wrap around to the negative-frequency terms. So, for an 8-point transform, the frequencies of the result are [0, 1, 2, 3, -4, -3, -2, -1]. To rearrange the fft output so that the zero-frequency component is centered, like [-4, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3], use

Transforms can be done in single, double, or extended precision (long double) floating point. Half precision inputs will be converted to single precision and non-floating-point inputs will be converted to double precision.
is real, a "real FFT" algorithm is automatically used, which roughly halves the computation time. To increase efficiency a little further, use
, which does the same calculation, but only outputs half of the symmetrical spectrum. If the data are both real and symmetrical, the
can again double the efficiency, by generating half of the spectrum from half of the signal.
is specified, the memory referenced by
may be used by the implementation in any way. This may include reusing the memory for the result, but this is in no way guaranteed. You should not rely on the contents of
after the transform as this may change in future without warning.
argument specifies the maximum number of parallel jobs to split the FFT computation into. This will execute independent 1-D FFTs within
must be at least 2-D and the non-transformed axes must be large enough to split into chunks. If
is too small, fewer jobs may be used than requested.
Length of the transformed axis of the output. If
is smaller than the length of the input, the input is cropped. If it is larger, the input is padded with zeros. If
is not given, the length of the input along the axis specified by
Axis over which to compute the FFT. If not given, the last axis is used.
Normalization mode. Default is "backward", meaning no normalization on the forward transforms and scaling by
factor on the forward tranform. For
can be destroyed; the default is False. See the notes below for more details.
Maximum number of workers to use for parallel computation. If negative, the value wraps around from
This argument is reserved for passing in a precomputed plan provided by downstream FFT vendors. It is currently not used in SciPy.
